captions.text:
From the man who created some of your fondest
childhood memories, then took a huge dump

Comes the prequel sequel that proved Phantom
Menace wasn’t an accident.
"This isn't how it's supposed to be."
Episode II: Attack of the Clones.
Once again the republic is in turmoil.

Watch as the chin-stroking Jedi are pulled
into a war between a completely disposable

droid army and a completely disposable clone
army.

Seriously, there is no reason to get emotionally
involved in any of this crap.

Experience an awkward, forced love story as
soulless as the computer it was made in

With so many visual effects, the filmmakers
didn’t have any time left over for things

"I'm haunted by the kiss that you should never
have given me."

"I don't like sand: it's coarse and rough
and irritating and it gets everywhere. Not

C'mon, JJ, there's no way you can do any worse
than this.

Natalie Portman and her space hair return
as Senator Padme Amidala.

When two of the galaxy’s best sharpshooting
assassins try to kill her with a poisonous
two Jedi warriors will come to her aid:

Obi Wan Kenobi, a man forced to act opposite
lifeless CGI characters like Hayden Christenson...

a rat-tailed a**hole who’s been creepily
stalking Padme for the last decade.

"I’ve thought about her every day since
we parted.”
"I don’t think she liked me watching her.”

"You're exactly the way I remember you in
my dreams."
"Please don't look at me like that."

Ride along with these one-dimensional heroes
in a movie so unevenly paced, you’ll have

to wait over an hour before you even meet
the main villain.

Instead, strap yourself in for even more of
the stuff that made Phantom Menace so cold,

One person standing and talking while another
is sitting and talking,

People standing and talking then taking a
seat for more talking,
Star Wars Episode 11: Attack of the Clones.

Correct me if I’m wrong here but the clones
never attack anyone in this movie. So why

the f*** would you call this movie Attack
of the Clones?!
Be sure to subscribe for more Honest Trailers.

title: Honest Trailers - Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones

comments.author: Carl Granieri

comments.text:
I think my main issue with the prequels is that they have awesome looking 
villains (Darth Maul, Jango Fett, General Grievous..even Dooku was at least 
cold and intimidating), yet they were all very underwhelming. We only saw 
Darth Maul fight twice (but I gotta say, the Naboo reactor fight has to be 
the best stuntwork in the entire franchise). Jango Fett had some prominent 
action but had an underwhelming death. General Grievous was supposed to be 
this Jedi killer, collecting all their lightsabers as trophies and whatnot, 
and he gets killed by a couple blaster shots. And Dooku, I really thought 
he was going to be the Vader of the prequels, but look how easily he got 
dispatched by Anakin in Revenge of the Sith (I know by this time Anakin is 
supposed to be one of the best Jedi Masters but Dooku's death was too 
easy). 

Besides the overly used CGI, the poor character & actor choices (Jar Jar, 
Hayden Christenson, and Jake Lloyd, etc), and some of the poor dialogue (I 
hate the sand), I thought the prequels were at the very least entertaining. 
They weren't these horrible movies that people had to labor through to see, 
at least for me..horrible in terms of Star Wars quality, but an 
entertaining film is still entertaining nonetheless. 

Speaking of "I hate the sand", that whole quote sounds sooo cheesy when 
taken out of context. But when you think about how Anakin used to live on 
Tatooine, a desert planet, it's easy to understand why he talks about it. 
It's still cheesy but when taken out of context like in a short clip, wow 
it's bad. Wow.

But seriously, "People sitting and talking, standing and talking, walking 
and talking, one person standing and talking while another is sitting and 
talking, people standing and talking then taking a seat for more talking" 
LOL﻿

comments.author: DoubleBarrell 456

comments.text:
What i find laughable in both prequels and sequels is how warfare is 
depicted. Totally without imagination or effort. I understand it in sequels 
since it was back in 70s-80s, and although modern warfare tactics were 
already developed, they weren't close for ordinary adolescent audience. But 
all those scenes (especially in prequel) of frontal warfare where two sides 
armed with freaking automatic ray guns just walk towards each other, mowing 
each other down, gets on my nerves. No tactics, no effort put into it so it 
would look realistic. Back to sequels, attack on Rebel base on snow planet 
is totally meaningless too (using hyper-tech weapons in WW1 style warfare) 
but again, that was sequels, made in time modern warfare wasn't so close to 
adolescent public. Also, whole Empire vs Ewok battle is totally idiotic and 
as if made specially for udner 10 kids. None the less, i hate prequels, 
love sequels, peace!﻿
